title: coming a musician
intro: Ever wanted to be a musician? Learn about life as a musician from some people around the UK who want to be successful musicians. Hear one of their songs and learn some useful vocabulary with Neil and Pippa.
this_week_question: Which artist has the most number one songs in the UK charts? Is it:
a)    The Beatles b)    Ed Sheeran c)    Elvis Presley
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: events where anyone can sing or play music
meetings for people interested in writing their own music
performing in a public place for money
someone who performs on the street or in public places

vocab.text: owe a lot (to someone or to something)
vocab.desc: have success or happiness because of that person or thing

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Pippa.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I’m Neil.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Now, Neil, have you ever wanted to be a musician?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh yes, Pippa, I still want to be a musician. I've been playing my guitar since I was 14.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Wow. Well, maybe one day you'll, you'll manage it. Who knows?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What about you?

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: I don't think I'd like to be a musician. I think it would be a bit stressful. Especially if you had lots of fans and were really successful.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah. I wonder what life as a musician is actually like? We’ll be finding that out in this programme as we hear from some people around the UK who would like to become successful musicians, and we’ll even listen to some of their music too.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: But first, I have a question for you, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh well, I think that's easy. It must be, surely, The Beatles.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Well, I’ll reveal the answer at the end of the programme.

transcript.author: Bailey Tomkinson
transcript.text: I grew up in a really rich music scene in St Ives. I was going to open mics from the age of about 11.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: This is Bailey. She lives in St Ives in Cornwall on the south-west coast of England. She says she was going to open mic nights from a young age. Open mic nights are events where anyone can sing or play music.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Bailey talked about her life as a musician to BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.

transcript.author: Bailey Tomkinson
transcript.text: I would go to these songwriters' circles at the Kettle and Wink on, like, a Friday night after school where I'd be, like, the youngest person by, like, 50 years. But I'd sit in a circle with a bunch of old men, and they'd play James Taylor and Carole King and The Eagles and lots of 70s music, and I guess that's influenced me massively. But I guess, you know, everyone kind of took me under their wing growing up.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When she was younger, Bailey went to songwriters' circles . These are meetings for people interested in writing their own music.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Bailey remembers sitting with a bunch of old men. A bunch is an informal way to talk about a group of people.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The older men in the group would play music from the 1970s, and Bailey says they took her under their wing . If you take somebody under your wing you decide to protect them or guide them.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Let’s meet another musician, Josh.

transcript.author: Josh Robinson
transcript.text: So, I learnt my first proper song on guitar when I was about 13. I literally started busking the moment I could kind of do that.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Josh lives in London and is a busker . This means that he performs on the street or in public places to earn money.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Busking is a common way for musicians to make money and perform to more people. And as Josh told BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home, it can help musicians to get new opportunities.

transcript.author: Josh Robinson
transcript.text: It's been kind of like my main earner that's kept me going for the last ten or so years. From that, it's then got me various different opportunities. It's got me all my gigs , it's got me all my connections. So I owe a lot to busking .

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Busking is Josh’s main earner , it’s his main source of money.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He says that busking has got him all his gigs and connections. Gigs are musical concerts. It’s an informal, slang word.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Josh says he owes a lot to busking. If you owe a lot to someone or something, you have success or happiness because of that person or thing.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Of course I would.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Well, here’s a bit of his song That Side of the Wall, which he performed for BBC Learning English programme My Song, My Home.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wow. Josh is pretty good, isn't he?. I’d love to hear more.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: Yes, I asked which artist had the most number one songs in the UK charts? The Beatles, Ed Sheeran or Elvis Presley?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Really? Well that's OK, I love 'the King' as well.

transcript.author: Pippa
transcript.text: OK.

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Pippa

transcript.author: Pippa
